Review title: One of the best movies/musicals ever
Review_body: Fiddler on the roof is one of the best movies ever made. It is not just because of the amazing acting and singing, but also because of the essence of the story. If there is one word to describe what this movie is about, then it is obvious that the word would be: Tradition We are losing tradition each and every year. I am an Orthodox Christian and tradition plays a big role in our faith. Losing tradition is like losing my way of life. The movie explains that feeling in many ways and the acting of Chaim Topol and the others associated with this picture adds to the greatness. This is a great musical that will go down in history for many years to come. May it never be forgotten. L'Chaim!

This movie had me wrapped up in the life story of this family.  You wept when they wept, and grew angry at the pogroms against them.  This is the story of a Jewish family, at the very beginning of the communist revolution. One sees the troubles they go through, as three of their daughters get married off.  Very emotionally engrossing.

The movie is essentially divided in two, the marriage of the 1st daughter, and part 2 of the other 2 daughters.The 1st one, I think is a genuinely good love story, of a father struggling against tradition & the happiness of his daughter.Meanwhile, the 2nd & 3rd marriage I simply consider bad parenting & bad reasoning.I ask you, the reader.Would you let your daughter marry a convicted political prisoner in Russia at such a time? To travel alone to Siberia to marry someone who may or may not be out of jail? What on earth is the excuse for her to go there and not stay with her family at least until he's out of jail?She's literally marrying the time's example of a "Political extremist"Then, there is Havas, which is simply stupid. In the movie, she barely even tries to get her father to accept. She doesn't make any ultimatums, didn't bring him to family dinner, didn't even properly introduce him.She absolutely abandons her family, without trying.Her "man" failed to even properly talk to her father.And worst of all, she's VERY young. This is VERY likely to just be unreasonable teenage infatuation, if I was supposed to support her marriage to that man, the movie writers utterly failed at making me like him or root for him.And worst of all, she didn't even bother to immigrate to New York with them!She could have kept contact! Lived close to her family!She purposefully, willingly & knowingly abandoned her family.If I rated this movie for the 1st half alone, it'd be a 9.If I rated this movie for the 2nd half alone, it'd be a 4.It was incredibly rushed on the 2nd half.And badly made.I still recommend giving the movie a watch. As the 1st half is incredibly well made, but, this already incredibly long movie, instead of just taking a break in the middle, just stop watching there,

Review title: One of my favorite movies of all time
Review_body: I saw this movie in the theater when I was 17 years old. Topol was excellent. It was amazing to me after watching this movie so many times that I had not noticed Paul Michael Glaser. I thought the casting was marvelous, the music unforgettable and the scenery beautiful. I grew up with my mother watching all musicals. I don't think I missed one. My children also grew up with musicals and I have shared this one with all 5 of them. I am a technical trainer and site some of the lines from this movie. When I was raising 5 children by myself, I recited the line "I know it is no shame to be poor, but it is no great honor either" often....

How could I give Fiddler on the Roof anything less than 10/10 when it is the closest thing any musical has come to perfection! Without a doubt, Topol's portrayal of Tevye, the Jewish peasant desperate to find good Jewish husbands for his daughters, is one of the greatest performances captured on film. He puts 100% into every little bit giving as perfect a performance at the end as he does at the start. For me, the highlight is still the ever-so-singable 'If I Were A Rich Man' which you almost can't sing without feeling the urge to shrug those shoulders in time with the music! But that sounds like I am dismissing the other wonderful songs which I most certainly am not. How could I when such beautiful melodies as that in 'Sunrise, Sunset' live long in the memory while the funnily desperate sentiments expressed in 'Matchmaker' just make you thankful we don't go through all that palaver to find a marriage partner these days... well, I didn't! :o) 1971, 35 years ago, not that far short of my entire lifetime, yet this musical feels as fresh and vibrant today as it did the day it was first released.I love musicals, I have a wide collection and play many instruments myself but nothing I have elsewhere in my collection nor anything I could ever produce on an instrument could ever come close to Fiddler. The greatest musical ever made into a film. Who cares that it goes on forever? Long may it do so! Cheers, Rob Barron
